pgTitle: List of giant squid specimens and sightings

rows.text: Found floating at surface, in process of washing ashore, alive
Dinoteuthis proboscideus More, 1875; Architeuthis monachus [fide Verrill]
Undetermined [NMI?]; holotype of Dinoteuthis proboscideus More, 1875
"longest tentacula": > fathoms (m); "body right from the head": fathoms (m); "so thick that a fullgrown man could hardly embrace it with his arms"
ZMUC; holotype of Architeuthis monachus Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Kristensen & Knudsen (1983:222)]
Steenstrup (1855:[14]); arting (1860:11); Steenstrup (1898:[258], pl.); Kristensen & Knudsen (1983:222)
Not stated; presumably found floating at surface
Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857; Architeuthis titan [fide Verrill (1875)]
WL: 377cm; AL: 1/2 whole length [fide Steenstrup]; beak measurements; GL: ft (m) [fide Verrill citing Harting]
Steenstrup (1857:[18]); Steenstrup (1882:[160]); Steenstrup (1898:[260, 298], pls. 3–4); Kristensen & Knudsen (1983:222); Glaubrecht & Salcedo-Vargas (2000:273)
Architeuthis dux [fide Harting (1860)]; Architeuthis hartingii (Verrill, 1875) [fide Verrill (1880)]; nomen nudum [fide Dell (1970:27)]
Jaws, buccal mass, detached arm suckers
Harting (1860:2, figs. 1–8); Verrill (1875b:85); Kent (1875:491); Verrill (1880:240); Pfeffer (1912:37)
Architeuthis monachus Steenstrup, 1857; Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Stephen (1962:154)]
Observed only by officers of the French gunboat Alecton; sketch made.
BL: in (cm); WL: in (cm); extensive additional measurements
NSMC; catalog no. 1870-Z-2; holotype of Architeuthis megaptera Verrill, 1878 [fide Macalaster (1977:14). Verrill specimen No. 21
BL+HL: ft5in (m); BC: ft (m); AL: ft6in (m)
In Kirk's possession; Kirk specimen No. 1
Meinertzhagen letter 27 June 1879 to Kirk; Pfeffer (1912:32); Dell (1952:98)
Mr. Meinertzhagen sent beak, saved by third party (unidentified), to Kirk. Natives called specimen a "taniwha".
Two; WL: ft (m) and WL: ft (m)
Data from Mr. Harvey letter citing Rev. M. Gabriel's statement to Harvey.
BL: ~ft (m); BD: in (cm); AL (mutilated): ~ft (m); AD: in (cm); AC: in (cm); beak; BC: ft8in (m); WT: lb (kg)
Jaws at NMNH [fide Verrill (1874a:158)][no longer extant?]. Verrill specimen No. 1
Packard (1873:91); Verrill (1874a:158); Verrill (1874b:167); Verrill (1875b:79, fig. 27); Verrill (1880a:181, 210, pl. 18 fig. 3)
Taken by Capt. Campbell, Schooner B.D. Haskins.
Found alive in shallow water, having been driven ashore in heavy sea
Entire; "one long arm missing" (later changed to both present)
BL: ft (m); BD: (–m); TL: ft (m); AL: ~ft (m); AD: in (cm); skin + flesh: in (cm) thick; EL: ft (m)

Specimen had a reddish colour. Verrill's data taken from newspaper accounts and 15/VI/1873 T.R. Bennett letter to Prof. Baird. more Verrill (1880a:186) states his No. 6 is same specimen as No. 3. [This cannot be correct, since capture date for No. 6 is clearly stated as December 1874 by Verrill (1875c:213).]
TL: ft (m); AL: ~ft (m); BL: ~ft (m) (estimate); BC: ft (m)
NMNH; Verrill specimen No. 4 (1875a:33); and possibly also Verrill specimen No. 11 (1875b:79)
Verrill (1874a:160); Verrill (1874b:167); Verrill (1875a:33); Verrill (1875b:79); Verrill (1880a:184, 187, pl. 16 figs. 5–6, pl. 25 fig. 5)
Material from Rev. A. Munn, through Prof. Baird to Verrill.
Packard (1873:91, fig.); Verrill (1875a:22); Verrill (1875b:79, figs. 25–26); Verrill (1880a:187, 210, pls. 17–20)
Verrill states Packard's illustration is inaccurate.
Megateuthis martensii Hilgendorf, 1880; Nomen spurium [fide Pfeffer (1912:31)]
'Entire', missing head, "abdominal sac", ends of tentacles and arms [fide Owen (1881:163)]
ML: 186cm; WL: 414cm; HL: 41cm; AL(longest): 197cm; ASD: 1.5cm (with 37 cusps); EyD: 200mm

ZMB Moll. 34716 + 38980, holotype of Megateuthis martensii Hilgendorf, 1880 [34716a: eyeball, 200mm diameter, dry; 34716b: pieces of arm and gladius, suckers; 34716c: larger piece of arm with suckers; 38980: four suckers from holotype arm piece]
Megaloteuthis harveyi Kent, 1874; Architeuthis monachus of Steenstrup [fide Verrill (1875a:34)]; ?Architeuthis harveyi [fide Verrill (1880a:181)]
YPM?; holotype of Megaloteuthis harveyi Kent, 1874; Verrill specimen No. 2
Owen (1881:161); Pfeffer (1912:19); Aldrich (1992:457); "February Naturalist pg. 120"; "13 December Field"; "6 December 1873 American Sportsman"
Found floating at surface, struck by Mr. T. Picot from boat, attacked boat.
?Architeuthis monachus of Steenstrup [fide Verrill (1874a)]; Architeuthis harveyi (Kent, 1874) [fide Verrill (1880a)]
In Verrill's possession; Verrill specimen No. 5

Verrill's data from letter to Dr. Dawson from M. Harvey. Photographs made of a) entire body, somewhat mutilated anteriorly; b) head and 10 arms. Poorly preserved; first in brine, then in alcohol. Capture date given as December several times, then as November several times and as November 25 by Aldrich (1992:457).
Architeuthis monachus [fide Kent (1874:178)]; Plectoteuthis grandis Owen, 1881; Architeuthis sp.? (grandis) [fide Verrill (1881:401)]; nomen nudum [fide Dell (1970:27)]
BMNH; holotype of Plectoteuthis grandis Owen, 1881
Seen from the steamers Strathowen and Pearl.
Architeuthis mouchezi Velain (1875:1002) [nomen nudum]; Mouchezis sancti-pauli Velain (1877:81)
Entire; found in advanced state of decay
Entire, except for tail (cut up for dog food)
EL: (–m); HL+BL: (–m); ?TL: ft (m); TL: ft (m); TC: in (cm); BL: ft (m); jaws
In Verrill's possession; Verrill specimen No. 6 and Verrill specimen No. 13

Data from 10/XII/1873 letter from Mr. Harvey to unknown individual citing measurements taken by G. Simms; Pfeffer (1912:21). Measurements are given differently in different papers. more Verrill (1880a:186) states his No. 6 is same specimen as No. 3. [This cannot be correct, as capture date for No. 6 is clearly stated as December 1874 by Verrill (1875c:213).] Verrill (1880a:188, pl. 17) repeats record as his No. 13.
Architeuthis princeps or Architeuthis monachus of Steenstrup
None; cut up, salted, and barrelled for dog meat
TL?: ft (m); BL+HL: ft (m); WL: ft (m); SD: ~in (cm)
Dr. Honeyman article in Halifax newspaper
Data from unidentified third party cited in Halifax newspaper article.
"destroyed before its value became known, and no measurements are given"
Beak and buccal mass, one arm, portions of both tentacles
TL: ~ft (m); CL: ft9in (m); CSD: in (cm); AL: ~ft (m); AC: in (cm)
Not stated; presumably found floating at surface
None; cut up for cod bait
Filled US gal (l) tub; ~lb (kg) (No. 25); TL: ft (m) (No. 26)
None; Verrill specimen No. 25 and Verrill specimen No. 26
Partial specimen; devoured by foxes and sea-birds
In Harvey's possession; Verrill specimen No. 15
M. Harvey letter 25 August 1877 to Verrill
(see 1880a:220) HL+BL: ft (m); BC: ft (m); TL: ft (m); AL (longest, ventral): ft (m); AC(ventral): in (cm); beak; FW: ft9in (m)
In Verrill's possession; Verrill specimen No. 14
Canadian Illustrated News, October 27, 1877; Verrill (1877:425); Verrill (1880a:189, pl. 17, figs. 1–10, pls. 19–20)
M. Harvey letter 17 November 1877 to Verrill citing reference to specimen by John Duffet
Specimen cut up and used for manure.
BL(+HL?): ft (m); TL: ft (m); AL: ft (m) (estimate)
M. Harvey letter 27 November 1877 to Verrill citing measurements taken by John Duffet

Found still alive, having "ploughed up a trench or furrow about 30ft long and of considerable depth by the stream of water that it ejected with great force from its siphon. When the tide receded it died."
Found aground off shore, alive; tied with rope and pulled to shore
None; cut up for dog food
M. Harvey letter 30 January 1879 to Boston Traveller; Hickey (2009)

Discovered by Stephen Sherring, fisherman. Often cited as the largest recorded giant squid specimen. Giant Squid Interpretation Centre and "life-sized" [-foot-long (m)] sculpture built near site of capture.
Entire, mutilated and with arms missing
None; cut up for dog food
BL+HL: ft (m); BC: ft (m); AL: ft (m)
M. Harvey letter 30 January 1879 to Boston Traveller
Found dead by William Budgell, fisherman, after heavy gale.
Steenstrupia stockii Kirk, 1882 [=Architeuthis sp.? fide Verrill (1882c:477)]
ML: ft2in (m); BC: ft3in (m); HL: ft11in (m); BL+HL: ft1in (m); HC: ft (m); AL: ft3in (m); AC: in (cm); ASC: 36; FL: in (cm); FW: in (cm) (single); GL: ft3in (m); GW: in (cm); other measurements
NMNZ; catalog no. M.125405 + M.125403 [fide Marshall (1996:45)]; holotype of Steenstrupia stockii Kirk, 1882. Kirk specimen No. 3
NMNH; catalog no. 576962. Verrill specimen No. 20
TL: 7680+mm; CL: 1010mm; CSC: 268; TSC: 290; additional indices and counts
Two arms with other mutilated parts
WL: ft (m); BL: ft (m); BC: ~ft (m); TL: ft (m)
Caught by fishing party. No other data.
Description sent to Mr. Beetham, M.H.R., by Mr. Moore
Found by Mr. Moore. No other data.
TL: in (cm); ASC: 330; extensive measurements and counts
YPM; catalog no. 12600y. Verrill specimen No. 24
Found dead by Capt. O.A. Whitten of schooner Wm.H. Oakes.
TL: ft (m); AL(I,II,IV): ft (m); AC(I,II,IV): in (cm); AL(III): ft5in (m); AC(III): in (cm); ASC(III): 71; HC: ft3in (m); HL: in (cm); ML: ft6in (m)
NMNZ; holotype of Architeuthis verrilli Kirk, 1882; specimen no longer extant [fide Marshall (1996:46)]
a) BL: ft (m); HL: ft (m); EL: ft (m); BC: ft (m) b) ML: ft (m); BC: ft (m); FL: ft (m); FW (single): in (cm); TL: ft (m); CL: ft (m); AL(ventral, minus tip): ft (m); TC(base): in (cm); etc.
Morris article in 25 November 1881 New York Herald; Morris article in 10 December 1881 Harper's Weekly; Pfeffer (1912:19)

Obtained by Mr. Morris, photographed by E. Lyons (St. John's), shipped on ice by steamer Catima to New York, purchased and preserved by E.M. Worth. Measurements by a) Inspector Murphy (chief Board of Public Works) when iced; b) Verrill of fixed specimen.
ML: ft3in (m); HL: ft9in (m); AL: ft6in (m); TL: ft10in (m); EL: ft10in (m); BC(estimate): ~ft (m)
NMNZ; catalog no. M.125404 + ?M.125406 [fide Marshall (1996:45)]; holotype of Architeuthis kirkii Robson, 1887. Kirk specimen No. 2
C.H.[W.] Robson letter 19 June 1879 to T.W. Kirk; Pfeffer (1912:35); Dell (1952:98); Dell (1970:27)
Found by Mr. C.H.[W.] Robson; beak given to Mr. A. Hamilton.
EL: ft2in (m); ML: in (cm); BC: in (cm); extensive additional measurements and description
Dell (1952:98[date found listed incorrectly fide Sweeney (2001:87)]); Dell (1970:27)
Found by Mr. Smith, local fisherman. Measurements taken by T.W. Kirk.
Entire, internal parts missing, preserved in alcohol; "exceptionally good condition" (Glaubrecht & Salcedo-Vargas (2004:55))

ML: 865mm; MW: 230mm; EL: 1740mm; HL: 160mm; HW: 190mm; FL: 440mm; FW: 600mm; TL: 720mm; CL: 225mm; AL(I): 460mm; AL(II): 450mm; AL(III): 500mm; AL(IV): 440mm; LSD(tentacle): 20mm; LSD(arm II): 15mm; LSD(arm II): 14mm; EyD: 80mm; Lens: 35mm
ML: 720mm; MW: 235mm; GL: 640mm; FL: 280mm; FW: 200mm; TL: 2910mm; extensive additional measurements and description
Caught in net after 2–3 day storm.
Dubioteuthis physeteris Joubin, 1900 [=Architeuthis physeteris (Joubin, 1900) fide Voss (1956:136)]
MOM; holotype of Dubioteuthis physeteris Joubin, 1900 [fide Belloc (1950:6); listed incorrectly as station 558]
TL: 1030+mm; CL: 900mm; CSC: 294; TSC: >298; LRL: 17.9mm; URL: 16.2mm; additional beak measurements, indices, and counts
VSM; VSM 110a [specimen NA-18 of Roeleveld (2000) and Roeleveld (2002)]
Brinkmann (1916:178, fig. 2); Nordgård (1923:11); Nordgård (1928:71); Sivertsen (1955:11); Toll & Hess (1981b:753)
BL+HL: 76cm; ML: 63cm; MW: 15cm; FL: 26.7cm; FW: 8cm; TL: 214cm; ASD: 8mm; TSD: 11mm
Young specimen taken by Michael Sars.
Length of arm given by whalers.
Found by schooner Annie Perry; attempted to be hoisted aboard but cut in half by rope; tentacle [arm] saved but later discarded.
Entire; "in very bad condition, there was no color left, and the epidermis had all sloughed off"
ML: ft (m); BC: ft (m); AL: ft (m); TL: ft (m); FL: ft7in (m); FW: ft9.5in (m)

ML+HL: 1550mm; ML: 1310mm; BD: 440mm; HW: 310mm; FL: 430mm; FW: 105; AL(I): 1780mm; AL(IV): 1640mm; TL: 5600mm [TL(R): 4925mm fide Roeleveld (2002:729)]; CL(R): 745mm; CSC(R): 262; TSC(R): 287; LRL: 15.8mm; URL: 15.9mm; additional beak measurements, indices, and counts
ZMUB; ZMUB 43689 [specimen NA-12 of Roeleveld (2000) and Roeleveld (2002)]
A little of the front part, tentacles and arms; remainder used for bait
With sucker response when found by J.F. Vaagan.
BL+HL: ft9in (m); FW: in (cm); AL: ft (m); AC: in (cm); TL: ft10in (m); CL: ft6in (m); other measurements and description
Observations by J. Ritchie after earlier mutilation of specimen by local boys. Colour drawing by Ritchie in NMSZ.
Architeuthis or Sthenoteuthis [fide Ritchie]; Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Stephen]
Sucker ring; beak lost, photograph only extant
Architeuthis harveyi (Kent, 1874); Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Stephen (1962:154)]
WL?: ~7.9m; ML: 1.37m; AL: 1.4–1.5m; TL: 6.4m; LRL: 15.0mm; URL: 13.7mm; additional beak measurements
Seen by members of the Godthaab Expedition.
Data from unpublished Ritchie manuscript; see Heppell & Smith concerning locality data.
ML: ft5in (m); MW: ft10in (m); FL: ft1.5in (m); FW (total): ft7in (m); numerous additional measurements
Architeuthis nawaji [fide Cadenat (1935)]; Architeuthis harveyi [fide Cadenat (1936)]
EL: 818cm; ML: 138cm; FL: 60cm; TL: 645cm; AL(IV): 112cm; AL(I): 110cm
ML: ft2in (m); BC: ft10in (m); FL: ft9in (m); FW: ft1in (m); TL: ft3in (m); HL: ft7in (m)
Frost (1936, figs. 1–10); Stephen (1962:155); Dyson (1982:107); see also
Architeuthis harveyi (Kent, 1874); Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Stephen (1962:154)]
Captured alive in trawl, tentacles and one arm cut off and remainder discarded. Date of capture incorrect in Heppell & Smith (1983).
Gerald Wood calls it "the largest known Architeuthis". Reference for measurements is "Karl Basilier, personal communication". Possibly the same as #114.
Head with arms and tail with fins
WL?: 1.75m ["totallaengde uden fangarme"; "total length without tentacles"]
Jaw, description, and sketch sent by Dr. Petersen and two suckers sent by Mr. J. Inkster to NMSZ.
Architeuthis sp. [fide Rae (1950)]; Architeuthis dux Steenstrup, 1857 [fide Stephen (1962)]
ML: 117cm; HL: 28cm; FL: 44.5cm; FW: 37.5cm; extensive additional measurements and description
Still exhibited some signs of life after being vomited.
ML: 92mm + 104mm; extensive additional measurements and description
ML: 1035mm; TL: 4480/3800mm; CL: 620/695mm; CSC: 248/248; TSC: 276/271; additional indices and counts

ML: 1010mm [970mm fide Roeleveld (2002:727)]; VML: 940mm; HL: 275mm; TL: 4900mm [4585/4785mm fide Roeleveld (2002:729)]; CL: 605/780mm; AL(I): 800mm; AL(IV): 1470/1530mm; LAL: 1530mm; HeL(IV pair): 90/130mm; PL: 780mm; SSL: 155mm; SoA: no obs.; SL: 110–180mm; CSC: 255/265; TSC: 286/280; additional indices and counts
Knudsen (1957:189, figs. 1–5); Roeleveld (2002:727); Guerra et al. (2004b:8)
Kjennerud (1958:1); Muus (1959:170); Stephen (1962:155); Roper & Young (1972:220); Toll & Hess (1981b:753); Aldrich (1992:476)

EL: 9.24m; BL: 2.14m; AL(shorter): 1.9m; TL(L): 7.1m; ML: 1.79m; MW: 0.57m; FL: 0.52m; FW(each): 0.18m; TSD: 2.6cm; ASD: 1.5cm; CL(L): 820mm; CSC(L): 254; TSC(L): >275; LRL: 15.6mm; URL: n/a; additional beak measurements, indices, and counts
VSM; VSM 156 [specimen NA-17 of Roeleveld (2000) and Roeleveld (2002)]
WT: lb (kg); EL: ft5in (m); WL: ft3in (m); ML: ft6in (m); BD: ft11in (m)
RSMAS [fide Rathjen]; no longer extant [fide Voss (1956:138)]
ML: 1829mm; WT: 127.9kg; extensive additional measurements and description
Arm suckers had no sucker rings [fide Dell (1970)]; likely dissolved after preservation in formalin per Roper & Young (1972:216).
EL: ft11in (m); ML: 940mm; BD: 343mm; TL(R): 4750mm; CL(R): 559mm; HL: 279mm; FL: 305mm; FW: 305mm
NMSZ; catalog no. 1957.20. Stephen specimen No. 3
Stephen et al. (1957:181); Stephen (1962:152, text-fig. 6, pl. 1 fig. 2); Heppell & Smith (1983:33)
Received from trawler Viking Prestige almost complete, but poorly preserved.

ML: 100cm; WT: 48kg; more VML: 87cm; BC: 80cm; FL: 28–32cm; FW: 26/33cm; HL: 30–32cm; HW: 25cm; AL(I): 126+ cm; AL(II): 143+ cm; AL(III): 126+ cm; AL(IV): 164cm; LAL: 164cm; AC(I): 16cm; AC(II): 20cm; AC(III): 22cm; AC(IV): 22cm; HeL(IV pair): 5–6cm; AF: 4.3.2.1; TaL: 10cm; FuL: 14cm; FuD: 7cm; FuCL: 12cm; FuCW: 2.5cm; PL: 92cm; SoA: yes; LRL: 1.2cm; URL: 1.5cm

ML: 57mm [56mm fide Roeleveld (2002:727)]; VML: 54mm; MW: 12mm; FL: 20mm; FW: 15mm; HL: 17mm; HW: 11mm; GiL: 16mm; AL(I): 47mm; AL(II): 59mm; AL(III): 58mm; AL(IV): 58mm; TL: 90mm [TL(L): 80mm fide Roeleveld (2002:729)]; CL: 25mm; ASD(I): 0.96mm; ASD(II): 1.04mm; ASD(III): 0.96mm; ASD(IV): 0.64mm; CSD: 0.96mm/0.40mm (medial/marginal); LRL: 1.0mm; URL: 1.2mm; extensive description and additional counts, indices, and beak measurements
NMNH cat. no. 727508 [specimen NA-34 of Roeleveld (2002)]
Roper & Young (1972:206, figs. 1a–c, 2–4, 5a); Roper (1992:99, figs. 160a–c); Roeleveld (2002:727)
Entire, sucker rings degraded and missing

ML: 45mm; VML: 43mm; MW: 8mm; FL: 14mm; FW: 11mm; HL: 11mm; HW: 9mm; GiL: 14mm; AL(I): 20mm; AL(II): 27mm; AL(III): 27mm; AL(IV): 28mm; TL: 33mm; CL: 14mm; ASD(I): 0.72mm; ASD(II): 0.88mm; ASD(III): 0.80mm; ASD(IV): 0.56mm; CSD: 0.56mm/0.24mm (medial/marginal); extensive description and additional counts and indices
Cestode found in caecum by Pippy & Aldrich (1969). Tentacular regeneration documented by Aldrich & Aldrich (1968:845, figs. 1–3).
Possibly seen alive in September on several occasions.
ML: 1190mm; TL: 5495/5307mm; CL: 745/722mm; CSC(L): 272; TSC(L): 300; additional indices and counts
Voss (1967:407, fig.); Aldrich & Brown (1967:6, fig.); Aldrich (1968:395, fig. 2)
ML: 161cm; BL(+HL?): 2.13m; TL: 3.66m; GL: 147cm; additional measurements
ML: 1115mm; TL(R): 4605mm; CL(R): 660mm; CSC(R): 250; TSC(R): 284; additional indices and counts
Entire; tentacles missing and arms incomplete
Aldrich & Brown (1967:8, fig.); Aldrich (1968:395, as 11 November)
Fiscus & Rice (1974:92, fig. 1); Fiscus et al. (1989:6); Fiscus (1993:93)
EL: 6m; WT: 35kg; TL: 3200mm [length of single extant tentacle]
Caught by the ship Matías Bengoechea.
Single architeuthid specimen from 905 examined albacore stomachs (of which 286 from "Region II").
Caught by the ship Saturno Juan.
Recovered dead by José Manuel Méndez and Bote Carducha.
Presented by Government of France in October, 1970.
ML: 41.5cm; BC: 26cm; AL: 32–49.5cm; TL: 140cm; FL: 20cm; FW: 8cm; plus estimates of other specimen weights from beaks
Collected by the boat Divino San Antonio.
Found floating at surface in visible state of decomposition
Found by fishermen Gus and Ken Garbes. Could not be towed in due to bad weather; pieces cut off for use as bait.
ML: 1450mm; extensive additional measurements, illustrations, and description
ML: 1700mm; LRL: 16.7mm; URL: 17.0mm; extensive measurements, illustrations, and description
SAM; catalog no. S1868 [specimen SA-2 of Roeleveld (2000)]
By trawl; taken by fisheries vessel
ML: 161cm; HL: 43cm; AL: 230cm; TL: 440cm; FL: 67cm; FW: 55cm
Entire, missing fins, tentacles, and arm tips
ML: 540mm; AL(IV): 830mm [longest arm IV, missing tip]
Caught by commercial fisherman G. Steffensmier.
Toll & Hess (1981a:768); Hess & Toll (1981:162, fig. 4); Roper (1992:99); Roeleveld (2002:736); Roper & Shea (2013:116)
Entire, missing long feeding tentacles, most arm tips, and skin; lost when the squid washed ashore
Roper & Boss (1982:96); Whalen (2009); see also and
ML: 50–77cm (ML(average): 62.5cm); additional measurements, indices, and descriptions
ML(estimate): ~500mm; TL: 1030/1570mm; CL: 311/357mm; CSC: 247/246; TSC: >273/>274; additional indices and counts
P. P. Shirshov Institute of Oceanology
One of the 18 specimens from record #226. Tentacle morphology examined by Roeleveld (2002).
ML(fresh): 164cm; FL(fresh): 75cm; FW(fresh): 43cm; description of thawed plus preserved specimen
Taken by R/V Novoul'yanovsk with 133m pelagic trawl.
Attempt made to haul aboard a tentacle weighing 100kg [?], but material was discarded upon observation of its poor state. Seen from the ship Oñaegea.
By trawl; taken by fisheries vessel
"likely to be of the genus Architeuthis"
At least head and arms; skin and eye(s) intact

Caught by ﬁsherman Henry Olsen. Photograph of freshly caught specimen taken by Ernie Choy at pier shows head with undamaged eye; used by Nilsson et al. (2012) to estimate eye and pupil diameter on basis of standard fuel hose visible in frame (findings of paper summarised by Partridge, 2012 and challenged by Schmitz, 2013 and Schmitz et al., 2013).
TL(fresh): 420 + 400cm; TL(fixed): 287 + 269cm; additional counts, measurements, and description
Captured by FRV Soela at 1450 hours.
Found by Secundino González and Manuel Pico.
By hook and line, caught alive
Brix et al. (1989:34); Hoving et al. (2006:158)
Caught in 5m deep bay; dying at time of capture. Blood study by Brix et al. (1989).

Entire; most of viscera missing, posterior tail and fins cut off, small piece of testis present, fragments of reddish membrane (which normally covers viscera) present, spermatangia deeply implanted in left arm IV (180–350mm from base)

ML: 900mm; MT(max.): 22mm; WT: ≥18kg (much lower than fresh mass); AL(I): 700+/750+ mm; AL(II): 610+/870+ mm; AL(III): 980+/790+ mm; AL(IV): 830+/940+ mm; TL: 810+/1040+ mm; EyD: 80mm; GiL: 250mm; FuD: 55mm; FuCL: 115mm; ASD(largest): 15mm [measurements taken after almost 25 years of preservation in formalin]
National Museum of Natural History, Leiden (public galleries)
NMSJ; catalog no. MO-1693. Aldrich specimen No. 15
"Had engaged in battle with what apparently was another cephalopod."
None; Gauldie et al. specimen No. 1
NMNZ; NMNZ M79971. Gauldie et al. specimen No. 1

Recovered tentacle: 5.5m long; TCL: 720mm; LSD: 28mm; ML(estimate based on TCL): 1615mm; ML(estimate based on LSD): 1709mm; WL(estimate): ~4.7m; EL(estimate): >8m

First widely reported images of live giant squid in its natural habitat. Feeding behaviour observed; "Architeuthis appears to be a much more active predator than previously suspected, using its elongate feeding tentacles to strike and tangle prey". Distal tentacle portion was still functioning upon retrieval at surface, with club suckers "repeatedly gripping the boat deck and any offered fingers".
Found floating at surface after having "had a tangle with a shark"
